p: The Réchy area (46°10′N, 7°30′E) is located on a mixed bedrock composed by gneiss, mica schists, quartzite, calcshists, marble, and cornieule and is shaped by geomorphological processes related to glaciers, gravity movements, and cryoturbation. A mosaic of acid and alkaline soils characterizes the area. Elevation of the vegetation plots ranges from 2328 to 2697 m a.s.l., namely the tree line ecotone and the lower alpine belt of the region. The area is the coldest and the driest among the three study sites, with a mean annual temperature of −0.53°C and 1480 mm of annual precipitations (Zimmermann and Kienast 1999). The annual sum of fresh snow thickness decreased by 24.1 cm, whereas the mean summer temperatures increased by +0.25°C per decade (Evolène, 1825 m; Fig. 2 and Appendix S1) during the 1987–2013 time span (no data available before).
